result.markdown:
--- title: "My Data Story" --- ## Visualization ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.3.2 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Attaching package: 'dplyr' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': filter, lag ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` The following objects are masked from 'package:base': intersect, setdiff, setequal, union ``` ::: ::: The variables that we are visualizing would be: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "gender" "parental_level_of_education" [3] "lunch" "test_preparation_course" [5] "math_score" "reading_score" [7] "writing_score" "average_score" ``` ::: :::
Gender and Average Score: Is there any difference between female and male? ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.3.2 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](datastory_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: :::
The median score appears to be higher for females than for males. However, the spread of scores appears to be larger for males than for females. One of the reasons for this might be that there are other factors besides gender that influence the test score, and these factors might have a larger effect on males than females. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Two Sample t-test data: study$average_score by study$gender t = 4.19, df = 998, p-value = 3.036e-05 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group female and group male is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 1.993744 5.506248 sample estimates: mean in group female mean in group male 69.5695 65.8195 ``` ::: :::
But, how about within each subject (Math, Writing, Reading)? ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](datastory_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](datastory_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-2.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](datastory_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-3.png){width=672} ::: :::
Interestingly, when both genders are plotted against all three subjects, males appear to score higher in all subjects. There could be a number of reasons for this. For example, males might be more interested in certain subjects than females, or they might have had better teachers in those subjects.
